questionListItems.title: How long will CPF Board take to give effect to the court order?

answer.body:
Upon receipt of your court order, the Board will generally take two to three weeks to give effect to the court order. As court orders differ in complexity, the CPF Board will need to review the relevant orders and will keep the lawyers and parties informed on the progress of the matter. 

We will upload the replies to you and your ex-spouse via your registered email address in our record or My Mailbox for members, and for law firms and the Legal Aid Bureau via My mailbox for business partners. An SMS or email notification will be sent to the My Mailbox recipient's mobile number or email address in our record.

topics.title: Other schemes
Division of CPF-related Assets in Matrimonial Proceedings

questionListItems.title: How do I submit my court order online?

answer.body:
You can submit your court orders for the division of CPF assets in divorce via my cpf Online Services ‘Submit Court Order for Division of CPF Assets in Divorce’.

For Members:

Scan or click the QR code, login with your Singpass, and complete the form accordingly:

Alternatively, you may submit the court order(s) using the following steps:

  1. At CPF website, login with your Singpass for my cpf Online Services
  2. Click on "My Requests" > "Other CPF Matters" > "Submit Court Order for Division of Matrimonial Assets"
  3. Complete the form accordingly

For Business Partners and Legal Aid Bureau (LAB):

If your lawyer or LAB is submitting your court order(s), they may scan or click the QR code, login with their Singpass, and complete the form:

Alternatively, they may submit the court order(s) using the following steps:

  1. At CPF website, scroll to the bottom of the page and click on "Business partners"
  2. Under “Business Partners Portal”, click on “Log in”
  3. Log in with Singpass
  4. Click on "Submit Court Order for Division of Matrimonial Assets"
  5. Complete the form accordingly

Note: If you, your ex-spouse or your lawyers cannot submit the court order(s) via our online service, you may make an appointment at our CPF Bishan Service Centre via Appointment@CPF for our Customer Service Executive to assist you with the submission. Please bring a copy of your court orders along with your identification document. 

CPF Bishan Service Centre
3 Bishan Place
#01-01
Singapore 579838
(near Bishan MRT Station)

topics.title: Other schemes
Division of CPF-related Assets in Matrimonial Proceedings

questionListItems.title: Is my ex-spouse entitled to have a share of my CPF savings upon our divorce?

answer.body: While CPF savings may be considered as matrimonial assets and a share may be given to your ex-spouse, there is nothing in the laws that give your ex-spouse an automatic entitlement. It is up to the Court to decide whether your ex-spouse is entitled to any part of your CPF savings, taking into account the matters set out in section 112 of the Women's Charter / section 52(3)(d) of the Administration of Muslim Law Act. For more information, please visit the Family Justice Courts’ website or Syariah Court’s website.

topics.title: Other schemes
Division of CPF-related Assets in Matrimonial Proceedings

questionListItems.title: How can I ensure that my court order for a transfer order or charging order meets CPF legislations?

answer.body:
Your court order must contain the following information:

  1. Legal provision of your ex-spouse’s entitlement for the CPF savings 
  2. The CPF Account that the transfer of CPF savings will be made from
  3. The amount of CPF savings to be transferred (the “Ordered Amount”). If the amount cannot be determined yet, the court order should state which party will be notifying the CPF Board of this information
  4. Triggering event upon which the CPF Board should transfer the Ordered Amount

In the absence of the above information, the CPF Board may not be able to comply with the provisions of the court order.

It is important to note that the use of CPF assets must be for the purpose of a division of matrimonial assets, and not for settling maintenance or personal claims or debts.

topics.title: Other schemes
Division of CPF-related Assets in Matrimonial Proceedings

questionListItems.title: What are your obligations after the court order is granted, before and following the transfer or payment of CPF savings to your ex-spouse in a divorce?

answer.body:
You are obliged to comply with the court order and shall not withdraw or transfer or attempt to withdraw or transfer any amount that your ex-spouse is entitled to under the court order.

In the event of a transfer or payment of CPF savings upon the making of housing refunds pursuant to a disposal of the property, loans or grants taken by you which are repayable or refundable to the Government must be repaid or refunded first before the transfer or payment of CPF savings can take place. Grants include housing grants from Housing and Development Board (HDB) and Home Ownership Plus Education (HOPE) grant from the Ministry of Social and Family Development 

Keep in mind that transferring or paying CPF savings to your ex-spouse might impact your participation in CPF schemes. If necessary, consider making alternative financial arrangements.

topics.title: Other schemes
Division of CPF-related Assets in Matrimonial Proceedings

questionListItems.title: Should I do a transfer or charging order for my CPF savings?

answer.body:
It depends on the intent of you and your ex-spouse, for the purpose of the division of CPF assets.

Transfer order

  • You and your ex-spouse don't need to wait until you are eligible to withdraw your CPF savings before they can receive her entitlement of your CPF savings.
  • You are not required to set aside your Full Retirement Sum.
  • Your ex-spouse can obtain a court order for a transfer of your CPF savings from any of your CPF accounts.
  • Your ex-spouse must be a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident at the time of the court order to be eligible for a transfer order.

Charging order

  • Your ex-spouse can be a Singapore Citizen, Permanent Resident, or a foreigner as at the time of the court order to be eligible for a charging order.
  • Payments can only be made to your ex-spouse when you become eligible to withdraw your CPF savings, typically when you turn 55.

If your ex-spouse is a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident: 

  • You need to set aside your Full Retirement Sum before we can make payment. 
  • The charge can only be imposed on the savings in your Ordinary and Special Accounts. 
  • If you have not set aside your Full Retirement Sum, the Board will only make payment of the Charged Amount or any part thereof to your ex-spouse. 

If your ex-spouse is a foreigner: 

  • You need not to set aside your Full Retirement Sum before we can make payment. 
  • The charge can be imposed on the savings in all your CPF accounts. 

You may refer to more information relating to transfer and charging orders.

topics.title: Other schemes
Division of CPF-related Assets in Matrimonial Proceedings

questionListItems.title: What happens if my CPF savings are not enough to fulfil my ex-spouse’s entitlement as required in the court order?

answer.body:
If your CPF savings are not enough to fulfil your ex-spouse’s entitlement as required in the court order, the Board can only effect the transfer or make the payment based on the available balances in your CPF account(s) as at date of transfer or payment.

You and your ex-spouse may wish to settle the shortfall amount privately or seek legal advice on the remedies available.

topics.title: Other schemes
Division of CPF-related Assets in Matrimonial Proceedings

questionListItems.title: As a member or an ex-spouse, what are my options if I am an undischarged bankrupt under division of CPF savings in a divorce?

answer.body:
The Court may still grant a transfer order or a charging order; similar to a member/ or an ex-spouse who is not an undischarged bankrupt. 

If you are the ex-spouse, and payment is to be made to you under a charging order, please check with the Official Assignee whether you can receive the CPF savings.

topics.title: Other schemes
Division of CPF-related Assets in Matrimonial Proceedings

questionListItems.title: Under a transfer order, do I need to set aside my retirement sum before my ex-spouse can receive their entitlement?

answer.body:
The transfer of CPF savings to your ex-spouse can take place without you setting aside your retirement sum* first. This gives your ex-spouse certainty over the amount they can receive and they can use them immediately for approved purposes such as housing, investment and education. Your ex-spouse may also withdraw the CPF savings when they are entitled to.

In the event of a transfer of CPF savings upon the making of housing refunds pursuant to a disposal of the property, the Board will first transfer the amount to your ex-spouse. Thereafter, the remaining refunds will be used to make up your retirement sum, up to your applicable Full Retirement Sum. Any balance refunds will then be paid to you. 

*Only applies to members aged 55 and above.

topics.title: Other schemes
Division of CPF-related Assets in Matrimonial Proceedings

questionListItems.title: Is there a limit on the CPF transfers that can be made to my ex-spouse’s CPF Accounts under the division of CPF savings in a divorce?

answer.body:
There is no limit on the CPF transfers if so ordered by the Court. It is up to the Court to decide on the division of CPF savings and how much your ex-spouse’s entitlement is.

Before the Court grants the court order, you should ensure that the Court is kept informed of any changes to the amount of CPF savings available for division or any planned utilisation of your CPF savings (e.g. deductions for housing payments) that would affect the division of the same.

topics.title: Other schemes
Division of CPF-related Assets in Matrimonial Proceedings

questionListItems.title: Can I specify the CPF account in which my ex-spouse is to receive the CPF savings under a transfer order?

answer.body:
For the court order to be workable, it must specify which of your CPF account(s) the transfer of CPF savings are to be made from. There is no need to specify which CPF account(s) your ex-spouse is to receive the monies in. This is because the transfers will be done in accordance with Regulation 3 of the Central Provident Fund (Division of Fund-Related Assets in Matrimonial Proceedings) Regulations which specifies the CPF accounts of the receiving party.

Please refer to the table below for more details:

From member's CPF account

To ex-spouse's CPF account

Ordinary Account

Ordinary Account

Special/Retirement Account

Special Account (if below age 55)
*Retirement Account (if age 55 and above)

MediSave Account

MediSave Account
 
* Any amount in excess of the Full Retirement Sum that your ex-spouse needs to set aside in their CPF Retirement Account, will be transferred to their Ordinary Account.

topics.title: Other schemes
Division of CPF-related Assets in Matrimonial Proceedings

questionListItems.title: Can I use the CPF savings immediately upon the receipt of the transferred monies from my ex-spouse?

answer.body: Yes, you can use the CPF savings for approved purposes such as housing, investment and education. You may also withdraw the CPF savings when you are entitled to do so.

topics.title: Other schemes
Division of CPF-related Assets in Matrimonial Proceedings

questionListItems.title: Under a transfer order, can I request the monies to be paid to me in cash, instead of transferring to my CPF account?

answer.body: Under a transfer order, the monies can only be transferred from your ex-spouse’s CPF account to your designated CPF account. If you wish to receive the monies in cash, you may consider applying to the Courts for a charging order instead.

topics.title: Other schemes
Division of CPF-related Assets in Matrimonial Proceedings

questionListItems.title: What do I need to do to receive payment under a charging order?

answer.body:
You will first need to submit the court order for the division of CPF assets via the online service "Submit Court Order for Division of CPF Assets". We will write to you and your ex-spouse once we have reviewed the court order.

When your ex-spouse is entitled to withdraw their CPF savings, we will write to you to inform you of the withdrawal procedure.

Once we receive your withdrawal application and the necessary documents, we will process the application and the monies will be paid to you within 10 working days through Inter-Bank GIRO and 15 working days via Telegraphic Transfer.

topics.title: Other schemes
Division of CPF-related Assets in Matrimonial Proceedings

questionListItems.title: After the transfer or sale of the matrimonial property has been completed pursuant to the existing court order, I reached a different agreement with my ex-spouse on the division of CPF assets. Can we undo the transfer or sale?

answer.body:
The CPF Board has no power under the relevant legislation to reverse the transfer or sale of the property.

You might want to seek legal advice on this.

topics.title: Other schemes
Division of CPF-related Assets in Matrimonial Proceedings
